data.text: Contents
Introduction

This policy promotes high quality appraisals and the systematic assessment of staff performance, development and career progression through an appraisal and ‘Check In' process which is fair and consistent with the Agenda for Change national terms and conditions.

There have been significant changes to pay award systems. This is linked to the appraisal process and MSEFTs new “Check-in Appraisal Guide” for all staff. All employees, appraisers and appraisees should familiarise themselves with this guidance in order to support pay progression decisions made in accordance with this policy.

The appraisal process plays a critical role in identifying individual contribution in the delivery of Trust objectives, giving individual's clarity about expectations and identifying learning, development and wellbeing needs.

The annual appraisal is a formal evaluation of an employee's job performance over the previous period by a supervisor or line manager to determine the degree to which they are performing effectively (and where relevant the pay step award). Appraisals are a joint responsibility between the individual (reviewee) and the reviewer in which expectations and outcomes are agreed and reviewed. This formal review must take place at least every 12 months and should form part of an ongoing process with frequent and regular check-ins.

The term ‘Check-in' is used to describe flexible, frequent conversations and continuous dialogue throughout the year. The new ‘Check-ins' supplement the ‘Annual Appraisal' and together provide a more effective, ongoing process beyond the traditional annual appraisal alone, which include opportunities to support wellbeing and development needs throughout an annual cycle of support.

Check-ins are a good opportunity to formally recognise successes and motivate staff, offer immediate, constructive and positive feedback, discuss career aspirations, wellbeing and training needs. Check-ins are best held at least quarterly, and more often if possible, to create an environment of reflection, support and compassion.

It is the responsibility of all staff to deliver their objectives consistently throughout the year and in accordance with Trust values and their associated behaviours. Individuals are expected to display appropriate levels of knowledge and skills in order to deliver the requirements of their role, and to communicate emerging support or development needs to their line manager that may impact on their ability to deliver these requirements.
The successful completion will be rewarded as outlined in the Agenda for Change terms and conditions.
Scope
This policy applies to all staff employed on Agenda for Change Terms and Conditions.

This policy specifically excludes Medical and Dental staff, Very Senior Managers and Senior Managers employed on local terms and conditions for whom separate policies exist which operate in accordance with the principles contained within this document. However these staff groups may choose to include aspects of this approach to supplement existing appraisal processes in order to support quality conversations around values, behaviours and wellbeing.
This policy also excludes those who work for the Trust but are not employed under a Contract of Employment for example agency workers, staff working under an honorary contract or bank only staff.
This policy has been developed in accordance to the revisions to Agenda for Change terms and conditions relating to pay progression applicable from st April

2019 and in accordance with the principles Annex  of the aforementioned. 2.5  This policy aims to ensure that all staff are clear about the required standards of performance, how this will be measured and how they will be supported in the achievement of these standards.  In terms of broader aims, this policy aims to:
Promote effectiveness and performance at work.
Promote equality and diversity.
Promote health and wellbeing
Form an integral part of performance management career and development support.
To achieve these aims the Policy will operate in accordance with the following principles:
Equity and fairness
Shift from automatic reward for length of service to performance and delivery by clear measurement of objectives and behaviours.
Objectives set must be within achievable for the individual
New starters
Newly employed employees to MSE are excluded from appraisal reporting for the first  days following their start date.

Staff who have transferred over from other organisations, under Transfer of Undertakings (Protection of Employment) Regulations (TUPE) 2006 (as amended 2014), are assumed to have an appraisal in place with their previous employer and are not excluded
Staff in substantive posts who previously held ‘bank only' contracts, have  days in which to have an appraisal following their substantive start date.
Definitions

table_items.text: The new overarching system that replaces the legacy appraisal processes.

The individual building block of ‘Check-In' process. Two way one to one meeting between a reviewer and a member of reviewee focusing on development and wellbeing needs and performance against objectives as part of an annual cycle of performance management.
The term Line Manager is used to refer to the person responsible for the day to day supervision of an employee, who also carries out the individual's ‘Check-In'
Any member of staff on a permanent or fixed term contract with the exception of medical staff and bank staff. This includes managers when they are being supported by their line manager.

The legacy appraisal model is the two way meeting held between Reviewee and Reviewer in which a review of performance for the previous 12 months takes place. This will include a review of the ‘what' and the ‘how' of the delivery of a set of objectives. Objectives will be set for the forthcoming year and the personal development plan put in place to support these.

Pay awards which are available to be earned by staff on their designated pay step date (the date on which they commenced in their current pay band) until the maximum point in the pay scale is attained. The ability to progress will be dependent upon measurement of performance and delivery as outlined in this policy.

Performance management is a holistic set of processes centered on two-way discussions and regular, supportive feedback of progress towards objectives and on values impact. It brings together many principles that enable good people management practice, including learning and development, wellbeing, performance measurement and organisational development. (CIPD,2020i)

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
The Chief Executive:
Cascade MSEFT Group objectives.
Chief People and Organisational Development Director:
Ensure that the system is appropriately resourced and delivers value to staff and through them to patients.
Care Group Leadership Teams:
Cascade Care Group objectives. People & OD
Workforce Information – Provision of reporting on appraisal
HR Business Partners – Advice and guidance to support the implementation of this policy, including supplying managers with information about Check-in completion rates and due dates.
Organisational Development – Development of this policy and providing support, learning and guidance to enable its implementation.
Line Managers:
Schedule and carry out regular check-ins with all individuals in their team to meet at least the minimum frequency required (quarterly).
Ensure any concerns regarding performance and capability formed part of prior discussion in advance of the appraisal in order to take remedial action at the earliest opportunity.

Schedule and carry out the annual appraisal and ensuring these are fully completed within the guidelines of the ‘Time to Connect' appraisal; including provision of quality feedback, support for objective setting, monitoring progress and development planning.
Undertake training to ensure knowledge and understanding of their responsibilities in relation to this policy and their equality responsibility.

Undertaking the appraisal no more than four months prior to and no later than the third (or the nearest working day) of the month immediately prior to the month in which the pay step is due. This will allow sufficient time for reporting and processing by the end of the month. For example, if a pay step date is th June the appraisal must occur between February th and May 3rd.

Conduct an objective review of the individuals work against the required standards as part of the annual appraisal process, which should include an assessment of the reviewees' achievement of any personal and / or organisational objectives including values and behaviours.
Agree an appropriate and resourced Personal Development Plan (PDP).
Review and submit evidence to demonstrate that the staff member has met the required standards, recording the outcomes of the appraisal.
Undertake a formal review of the pay progression decision where appropriate and complete all necessary processes to record this decision.
Ensure that an appropriate plan of training and support is available for staff who are not awarded a pay step in any given year.
Ensure no discrimination or bias towards any ‘Protected Characteristic' group in the application of this policy.
All Staff:
Participate in the check-in appraisal process each year, regardless of whether or not their next pay step date is that year and complete documentation referencing evidence in a timely fashion.
Productively and collaboratively schedule check-ins with their line managers to meet the minimum frequency required.

Jointly agree their objectives and personal development plans with their line manager and make them aware if there is anything that is preventing them from achieving these objectives or undertaking relevant training.
Maintain their own professional and personal development and review their own performance against objectives, values and behaviours and prepare effectively for check-ins and appraisals.
Ensure that all relevant statutory, mandatory and essential skills training is up to date and liaise with their line manager if they are experiencing difficulties
achieving compliance.
Appraisal process overview

This policy is designed to raise levels of staff engagement, wellbeing and performance in order to improve quality of patient care whether individuals are directly or indirectly involved in the delivery of care. Individuals who meet required performance levels will be rewarded with a pay step where applicable. It is also designed to raise the quality of performance management in the Trust to support staff development, engagement and wellbeing.
In the event that performance standards are not met, principles outlined in the Performance Improvement Policy will apply.
Measurement within the Appraisal Process:

An overall picture of the employees performance across the appraisal year can be collated from the three previous check-ins and evidence provided by other parties, e.g. 360 degree feedback. This needs to consider factors that may have affected their ability to perform e.g. period of time out of work due to maternity leave or long term sickness or significant changes to the work of the team that may have made objectives redundant.
Assessment and feedback on task and values performance should be completed regularly regardless of if the individual is due to progress through a pay gateway.

The rating scales below help to evaluate success, based on achievement against objectives and observed values based behaviours. These should be recorded on the appraisal form (this form is found in the appraisal guide and in the Appendices of the Policy for illustrative purposes but should be completed electronically).

Other factors are also taken into consideration for making a pay step award, such as completion of relevant Statutory and Mandatory training and other HR process all cited on the Pay Step Form (e.g. sanctions or capability processes).
Figure 1: Objective status scale

table_items.text: All objectives and success measures have been achieved. Delivered over and above
100% Complete (Progress to next pay step where applicable)
Satisfactory to good progress and majority of objectives met
75% to 99% Complete (Progress to next pay step where applicable)
Little progress and objectives only partially met, less than half achieved
50% to 74% Complete (Do not progress to next pay step where applicable)
Under 50% Complete (Do not progress to next pay step)

data.text: Figure 2: Values based behaviour observation frequency scale

table_items.text: Colleagues in contact with this person observe values based behaviours consistently
Progress to the next spinal point on the step pay award
Colleagues would generally report the individual mostly demonstrates appropriate values based behaviours (with evidence of acting on feedback where relevant)
Progress to the next spinal point on the step pay award
Values based behaviours are only partially observed on an infrequent basis and there is a clear development opportunity with little evidence of taking action on feedback
Do not progress to the next spinal point on the step pay award
Values based behaviours are rarely observed - needs immediate improvement
Do not progress to the next spinal point on the step pay award.

Mandatory training incomplete (unless it is due to mitigating circumstances e.g. maternity leave, long term sickness; training is cancelled due to winter pressures/pandemic, staff are not given access to a computer to undertake the training; or managers do not allocate time; or there is an issue with provision of training.)
Formal Sanction under Disciplinary and Performance Improvement Policies (review and discuss in line with HR policy, procedure and Staff side)

data.text: Appraisal process steps

Step One Preparation - Prior to the appraisal meeting (2-3 weeks) the reviewee and reviewer will individually assess and score the previous years' objectives in terms of delivery and approach and record evidence, feedback and reflections relating to behaviours and impact.

Step Two Review - At the appraisal meeting, the reviewee and reviewer and agree the above scores and agree the overall performance score. Using this score  and  an  assessment  of  the  objectives,  behaviours  and  HR  measures summarised, a decision is made on pay step award where relevant. At the review the reviewee and reviewer should also address any wellbeing needs or issues that are relevant.

Step Three Plan -  Reviewee and reviewer will agree objectives for the forthcoming year and plan development needs. If appropriate, particular attention will be given to raising performance to the required standard in the forthcoming year, through appropriate training and support.

Step Four Line Manager Sign off - The reviewer's line manager will ensure consistency and fairness and undertake formal ‘reviews' where necessary. They will ‘sign off' all appraisal documentation. Where a pay step has not been awarded, the reviewer will not refer the appraisal for ‘sign off' until 14 calendar days have lapsed to allow sufficient time for the employee to request a review. The review option does not apply to staff at the top of their pay scale.

SMART Objectives (Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Realistic, Time- Bound) Objectives will be set which meet the standards outlined in the Appraisal Guidance and must be measurable and achievable with sufficient stretch and challenge. Wherever possible, objectives will be standardised and linked to global Trust or Team objectives.
Pay step submission process
The pay step submission process is as follows:
Line managers will receive notification before an individual's next pay step date and initiate a meeting to review whether the requirements for progression have been met.
The pay step decision must be recorded by completion of the appraisal process detailed in this policy.
This will then be used as the basis for confirmation of movement to the next pay step point.
Pay step points will be closed on the payroll system. Once the pay step review has been successfully completed the line manager must take the necessary action to open the pay step point.

Line managers must ensure that the pay step submission process is completed in a timely fashion to ensure that pay step points can be implemented in time for the staff member's pay step date. This must take account of local payroll timescales.

If the last appraisal outcome was not satisfactory but remedial actions have been successfully completed by the time of the pay step date the staff member will be able to progress without delay if they meet the other standards.
Decisions to defer a pay step

Pay progression should not be deferred on performance grounds unless there has been a prior documented discussion between the staff and their line manager regarding failure to meet the required level of performance and the staff have been given a reasonable opportunity to demonstrate the required improvement before a decision on pay progression is taken. This prior discussion would need to identify areas for improvement and any reasonable developmental support the staff may require to operate at the required level of performance. Line managers must ensure that any development support identified is provided to the staff in order to meet the performance standards.

It is expected that staff will achieve the required standards at the point of their pay step date. It is also expected that staff and their line manager should have regular discussions about any problems in reaching the required standards before the pay step date. This will allow time for issues to be raised and possible solutions found to enable the pay step point to be opened on time.

Where factors beyond the individual's control, such as organisational or operational issues, have prevented compliance these should not prevent the employee from progressing. Managers must ensure they take full account of such factors and staff should bring these to the attention of their line manager as soon as possible (not waiting for the pay step review) so that these can be addressed and remedied.
In situations where standards have not been met, and there are no mitigating factors sufficient to justify this, it is expected that an individual's pay step will be deferred.

The line manager must use the annual appraisal and pay step review meeting process to discuss the standards that have not been met and review previous discussions about these, consider any mitigating factors, and record their decision in the appraisal paperwork.

The line manager should advise the member of staff of their right to contest any decision using the review process within the policy where the required level of performance is deemed not to have been met in line with the local policy. If this is upheld, the pay step should be applied backdated to the pay step date.

The line manager should also discuss and agree a plan with the staff member for any remedial action needed to ensure that the required standards for pay progression are met, including a timescale, and how any training and support needs will be met.
The staff member must take all necessary steps to meet the requirements as soon as possible and the line manager must provide the necessary support.

A further pay step review meeting should be arranged at an agreed date to review progress and, where satisfactory, initiate the opening of the pay step. The effective date for progressing to the next pay step should be the earliest date that the relevant requirements are shown to have been met. The pay step date for future years will remain unchanged.

Where  a  pay  step is  delayed  due  to  a  ‘live'  disciplinary  sanction,  or  a  formal performance improvement process, the line manager should initiate a pay step review meeting before the expiry of the sanction or capability plan. This should be used to confirm that all other requirements have been met and to ensure that the staff member progresses to the next pay step, effective the day after the sanction expires. The pay step date will remain unchanged.
A disciplinary sanction cannot be applied retrospectively to defer a pay step if it comes into effect after the pay step date.
Re-earnable process for bands 8c, 8d and
The principles and standards for pay progression and then re-earnable pay for staff in bands 8c, 8d and 9 are the same as the principles and standards for all other staff.

Once they have reached the top of their band, the expectation is that all staff will meet the required standards and will re-earn the relevant element of pay annually. The first point at which the re-earnable element becomes relevant is 12 months after employees have passed through their pay step point to reach the top of the band.

In the year after an employee has reached the top of bands 8c, 8d or 9, 5% or 10% of basic salary will become re-earnable. Where the standards are met, salary is retained at the top of the band. If standards are not met salary may be reduced by 5% or 10% from the pay step date. The employee will be able to restore their salary to the top of the band at the end of the following year by meeting the required standards. The employee has the right to contest a decision to reduce their pay using the locally agreed procedure.

Staff on the top two points of these bands on 31 March 2013 have reserved rights to the relevant point. This reserved right will be retained on a marked time basis. At the end of 2020/21, 5% of pay will become annually earned and then, when annual increases to the top of the band add a further 5%, annually re-earnable pay will change to 10% of the basic pay.

The application of the annually earned 5% and 10% will only come into effect following the implementation of clearly defined parameters from NHS Employers and / or a review of the MSEFT appraisal process.
Pay progression arrangements during pandemic

A pandemic may have multiple and significant impact on staff. Pay step meetings should continue during a pandemic however Reviewer's must recognise that Reviewees may not have had the usual opportunities to raise any issues during pandemic and must be given the opportunity to raise these impacts during the pay step meeting.

In instances where staff are absent from work due to reasons related to a pandemic when their pay step meeting is due, then the principle of equal and fair treatment should apply to ensure staff do not face a detrimental impact.

Managers must take into consideration that adjustments may need to be made to the improvement plan or to the backdating if it will take the employee longer to complete the process because of the pandemic circumstances.
Any changes to the appraisal process during pandemic will be in line with national guidelines and the decision will be communicated to all staff.
Absent from work when pay step is due

If a staff member is absent from work for reasons such as sickness or parental leave when a pay step is due, the principle of equal and fair treatment should be followed so that no detriment is suffered as a result.

In the case of planned long-term paid absence such as maternity, adoption and shared parental leave the pay step review can be conducted early if this is reasonable and practical, allowing the pay step to be applied on their pay step date in their absence.

If an individual is on long-term paid absence such as maternity, adoption and shared parental leave and a pay step review cannot be conducted prior to the pay step date; the pay step point should be automatically applied in the individual's absence.

If there was a live disciplinary sanction in place at the point the individual went on leave, the pay step point should be applied in their absence if appropriate, effective the day after the sanction expires.

If there was an active formal capability process underway at the point they went on leave, the pay step point can be delayed. The improvement process should be resumed immediately upon their return. On satisfactory completion, the period of their absence should be set aside and the pay step point backdated to an agreed date as if they had completed the improvement process without being absent. Manager's will need to take particular care to avoid any discrimination or detriment on the grounds of maternity, race, sex or disability that could arise in relation to staff on maternity/adoption/parental leave or sick leave.

Suspension from work on full pay is a neutral act. In order to ensure that this is the case, employers should ensure that the pay step point is applied from the pay step review date where an individual is suspended on that date, provided they were meeting the required standards (refer to Appendix 6).
Retrospective pay step awards
There are two circumstances in which pay steps may be applied retrospectively:
Completion  of  Core  training  within   weeks  of  appraisal date  or  review  of Disciplinary or Capability sanction. A clear communication should be submitted to HR stating:
In exceptional circumstances where an appraisal has been delayed not through the fault of the individual. A clear communication should be submitted to HR stating:
Review
Staff will be able to request a review of any decision undertaken by their reviewer with regard to pay progression, as outlined below.
Every effort should be made to ensure that the reviewer and reviewee are able to resolve differences of opinion during the appraisal informally.
If there is a disagreement about any aspect of the appraisal process or annual appraisal meeting, either party can approach the next line manager, for assistance to resolve the issue.
An individual must request a review in writing within 14 calendar days of the receipt of the pay progression decision wherever possible.
The reviewer's line manager must undertake the review within a further 14 calendar days of this request wherever possible.

The reviewer's line manager will review the scoring and evidence and any mitigation presented in order to evaluate the objectivity of the scoring taking into account the complexity of the objective. The score will be benchmarked with others in the team.
If the line manager has been involved in advising the appraising manager regarding the disciplinary/capability sanction previously, the review will be referred to the next level of decision making.
The decision of the reviewer's line manager is final.
Training requirements
All reviewees and reviewers will receive guidance or have access to training as appropriate on this Policy in order that the criteria and process are understood and there is consistent application.
Training is available for both reviewers and reviewees with details available on the MSEFT intranet.
Monitoring and audit
Outlined  below  is  the  Trust's  process  of  monitoring  compliance  with,  and  the effectiveness of the document's main points.

data.text: Approval and Implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the HR Policy Working Group, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Document Management Group of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.  (Refer to appendix 7).

Appendix 1: Preparing for your Time to Connect Check-ins and appraisal – guidance

The questions below are intended to help prepare for Check-ins and Appraisal. They can be used to help the line-manager and member of staff think about the past year and make notes to take to the Time to Connect meeting.
The Time to Connect meetings are opportunities to share thoughts and feelings and discuss roles and responsibilities.
Below are some questions or prompts to raise awareness and prepare for the conversation.
Self-care - How do you look after your own wellbeing? (Physical activity, healthy diet, coping strategies)
Wellbeing at Work - What helps you to stay well at work? (Taking breaks, getting away from your desk, connecting with colleagues)
What do you or others notice when you are stressed? (Difficulty to prioritise, irritability, problems with your memory or concentration)
As a manager, what can I do to support your wellbeing at work? (Regular feedback, more 1:1 support)
Adjustments & Support – Are there any support or reasonable adjustments that you need to support your wellbeing at work? (Workplace adjustments, flexible working arrangements, workplace aids)
Are your Equality and Diversity needs being met?
Your stand-out moment, something you are proud of. What did you do well?
Your work objectives. Have you made progress in achieving them?
Something that your team has achieved.
Something you've learned or improved on.
Workload.
Something you've found challenging.
Your skills and knowledge. Have you made progress in developing these?
Organisational values and behaviours. How have you demonstrated these in your role?
Relationships with colleagues.
Support you may need from your manager or colleagues
Ideas for future objectives
Reflecting on your learning and development and its impact.
Updating your personal development plan (PDP).
Listing the opportunities you have had to learn something new.
What support or development would help you in your role?
What you'd like to do more of in your role. What are your career aspirations?
How can you fill your development gaps/learning needs?
Anything else you want to discuss

table_items.text: ☐ A change in a service to patients
☐ A change to an existing document
☐ A change to the way staff work
What are you proposing to change?
Why are you making this change? (What will the change achieve?)
Who benefits from this change and how?
Is anyone likely to suffer any negative impact as a result of this change? If no, please record reasons here and sign and date this assessment. If yes, please complete a full EIA.
a) Will you be undertaking any consultation as part of this change?
